channel.title: [Discussion] Strict Cross Linking
channel.description:
So my feature request is an option to have strict cross lining like many other personal knowledge apps like Obsidan/Roam/etc. so right now I run into the following issue:
I create a note that represents a person like so: ![image|499x440](upload://uNeEu0SJYnSFvIsLNwqv2n3tWHL.png) I then have a meeting with person and create a note: ![image|482x438](upload://q2yLqlwqbAtuviyBDM8cbLLB416.png) I then want to link to the person in a different note: ![image|480x439](upload://2ulXcdSbBSZDJLoy0IdY1enWcnH.png) Clicking on the name brings up this: ![image|482x446](upload://xSB8wBtAWmYAFMJFGuO87ZsktcR.jpeg)
So to make this work like it does in other apps I would have to go and remove the name from any note title or start adding zettelkasten style ids to every title.
So the feature request would be to an option that's say "cross linking strict mode" where links with [[]] only link to notes that exactly match (maybe we ignore the `# ` commonly found in titles), so [[Jeff Bezos]] only links to a note that has `# Jeff Bezos` as the title and creates one if it doesn't exist even if there's a note with a title like "# 2020-10-16 Jeff Bezos meeting".

item.title: [Discussion] Strict Cross Linking
item.dc:creator: agiletortoise
item.description:
Definite some good feedback in this thread.

Linking by title is always going to be less reliable than using unique identifiers and require a certain amount of discipline. If you want 100% reliable links, use [[u:UUID]] format links. Not human readable, yes, but totally reliable and resilient in cases of title changes, etc.

Be aware that while this is a feature of Drafts, Drafts is never going to be purpose-built around optimizing for this cross-linking - it is a multi-purpose tool.

Link identifiers and the links they create are dynamically defined in syntax highlighting definitions, and I‚Äôm working hard on getting custom syntax support out - it‚Äôs the next ‚Äúbig‚Äù feature on the road map now that support new OS features for the Fall is getting wrapped up‚Ä¶so that will open up a lot of customization options for additional/different ways to do markup for links (see format preview docs).

Some of the other things you are talking about - like behaviors when multiple matches are found - would require some other minor tweaks to parameters supported in Drafts /open URL scheme, I‚Äôm sure I can make some of those modification (like being able to suppress the multiple draft warning).

item.title: [Discussion] Strict Cross Linking
item.dc:creator: Bjb
item.description:
@jsamlarose - I think you have forwarded two really good ideas that would go far towards removing the rough edges of this evolving (and very powerful) capability:
1. Create an exact match link option, e.g., [[x: ‚Äúexact title‚Äù]]
2. Remove the warning message in the event that multiple matches are found following a fuzzy search.
As you point out, a fuzzy search should be viewed as a feature, not as a problem. Being able to find any title with a particular word or phrase in it has real benefits, especially if you use long titles to make them as descriptive as possible.

I‚Äôd like to suggest two refinements to your ideas:

  1. The exact search method should strip Markdown headers. It would therefore be ‚Äúalmost exact.‚Äù
  2. When an ‚Äúexact match‚Äù link is constructed, it is important that spelling, case, plural variations, etc. not get in the way of creating ‚Äúexactness.‚Äù Therefore, I recommend that after the first one or two letters are entered after ‚Äú[[x:‚Äù that a list of matching titles be displayed and progressively narrowed as each letter is added to the link. Choosing from a list of potential matches is the best way to ensure that ‚Äúexactness‚Äù is achieved.

Read full topic

item.title: [Discussion] Strict Cross Linking
item.dc:creator: jsamlarose
item.description:
I hope this isn‚Äôt derailing the original feature request, but to offer yet another alternative: it would actually be really useful if, instead of the ‚Äúmultiple drafts match‚Äù warning, the quick search window was invoked immediately, and the closest exact/strict match was given preference and sorted to the top of the list of returned matches.

This would truly be the best of both worlds. No syntax or symbols to remember, no additional behaviour to learn, yet we‚Äôd still have all the benefits and discoverability of the current fuzzy searching.

I know it‚Äôs designed to be helpful, but when I see the current ‚Äúmultiple drafts match‚Äù message, I can‚Äôt help feeling like I‚Äôve done something wrong in failing to ensure the uniqueness of my titling/links. And it‚Äôs a bit of a speed-bump. I‚Äôd prefer the quick search response to multiple drafts that match a wiki-link to feel more like a useful feature than a warning.

item.dc:creator: Andreas_Haberle
item.description:
Maybe there is a small misunderstanding.

Drafts does the following with wiki style links:

  • Fuzzy Search for title
  • check if more than one result in title field
  • NO, open title
  • Yes, feed link to a search box

The strange thing is that the search box will search not only in the title field and also show the derart a that have the search term in the body.

If you prefix the title of the person draft AND into your wiki links. Draft will only find one result and open it.

Meeting Note:

# Meeting 2020 Some Name

....

Person Note:

# P: Some Name 

Personal page

Link Example:

Test Reference

[[P: Some Name]]

  • Arranged meeting with [[Jeff Bezos]] to discuss [[my new yacht]] on [[October 30th, 2020]]

This block would appear in four different ROAM ‚Äúpages‚Äù (where a page is roughly analogous to a draft in Drafts):

[[Jeff Bezos]]
[[my new yacht]]
[[October 30th, 2020]]
the page used for the entry - typically "today‚Äôs page

Seeing it in any of the four different contexts provided by these four pages might be desirable at any given time.

Mapping this functionality into Drafts is a problem too hard for me to solve. Drafts does stuff that ROAM does not - but I don‚Äôt think it does this particular thing - except maybe with a disciplined use of tags.

item.title: [Discussion] Strict Cross Linking
item.dc:creator: Bjb
item.description:
I‚Äôm not sure that I agree with your idea.

With Roam the first instance of [[Jeff Bezos]] would create a new ‚Äúpage‚Äù (‚Äúdraft‚Äù in Drafts) titled Jeff Bezos.

Thereafter, any use of [[Jeff Bezos]] such as:

  • Met with [[Jeff Bezos]] to discuss my plans to buy a yacht.

would exist on the page where it was entered, but also be added to the Jeff Bezos page.

[[Jeff Bezos]] does double duty in Roam ‚Äì it links you to a page if you click on it, and it also adds any entry with [[Jeff Bezos]] embedded in the entry to the Jeff Bezos page, regardless of where the entry was made. There could be a dozen [[Jeff Bezos]] entries ‚Äì none made on pages with ‚ÄúJeff Bezos‚Äù in the title.

But, Drafts doesn‚Äôt perform the ‚Äúcollection‚Äù function. Therefore, if you clicked on [[Jeff Bezos]] using your plan, you would see only a fraction of the information related to Jeff.

In Drafts, the assumption is that you would link to drafts using more descriptive titles:

[[Jeff Bezos meeting re my yacht]]
[[Jeff Bezos is a rich guy.]]
[[Jeff Bezos keeps asking to borrow my lawnmower.]]

Each is a separate subject, residing on separate drafts, accessed through different links. If you search for [[Jeff Bezos]] Drafts shows you all the Jeff Bezos titles ‚Äì and you can pick what you want.

Otherwise, I don‚Äôt know how you would be able to find all the information related to our pal Jeff.
